(I don't post here often, but this talk has been eye-opening.)

Hi Ken. I u=
nderstand your concern. It's certainly a valid one.

(I could be totally wr=
ong. I wish I paid more attention in my statistical mechanics class.)

From=
 my understanding of the talk, each pre-training abstract the representatio=
ns from the inputs of the previous layer. So even if the original layer of =
input is individual pixel, it's very possible that the 2nd or the 3rd layer=
 contains geometry representations. Otherwise, I can't imagine it will do w=
ell in generating such a wide variety of styles of digits.

If we want to u=
se this network on tasks of different resolutions, I'm willing to hypothesi=
ze that we can just chop off the pixel layer, attach a higher resolution in=
put layer, and retrain only the new connections.

Better yet, re-train thos=
e connections using hyperNeat.

Does that sound sensable?
